By incorporating these features, patrons will have a user-friendly and efficient browsing experience, allowing them to locate the needed resources by author or subject area with ease.

input: As a DB/IR administrator, I want to manage subject classifications for ease of patron browsing and searching.
result:
To effectively manage subject classifications for ease of patron browsing and searching as a DB/IR (Database/Information Retrieval) administrator, you can follow these steps:

1. Understand the Library Classification System: Familiarize yourself with the library classification system being used in your organization. Common systems include Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC) or Library of Congress Classification (LCC). This will help you understand the structure and hierarchy of subject classifications.

2. Analyze User Needs: Identify the needs and preferences of your patrons. Conduct surveys or gather feedback to understand how they prefer to browse and search for information. This will help you tailor the subject classifications to their requirements.

3. Create a Controlled Vocabulary: Develop a controlled vocabulary for subject classifications. This involves creating a list of authorized terms or keywords that will be used consistently across the database. This ensures uniformity and avoids confusion among patrons.

4. Assign Subject Headings: Assign appropriate subject headings to each item in the database. This can be done manually or through automated processes, depending on the size and complexity of the database. Ensure that each item is tagged with the relevant subject headings to facilitate browsing and searching.

5. Establish Hierarchical Structure: Organize subject classifications in a hierarchical structure to reflect the relationships between different subjects. This allows patrons to navigate through broader and narrower subject categories easily. For example, a book on "Animals" can be categorized under "Biology" and further under "Zoology."

6. Maintain Consistency: Regularly review and update the subject classifications to ensure consistency and accuracy. Remove outdated or irrelevant terms and add new ones as needed. This will enhance the browsing and searching experience for patrons.

7. Provide Search Filters: Implement search filters based on subject classifications. This allows patrons to refine their search results by selecting specific subject categories. It improves the precision and relevance of search results.

8. Train Staff and Patrons: Educate library staff and patrons about the subject classifications and how to effectively use them for browsing and searching. Conduct training sessions or provide user guides to ensure everyone understands the system and its benefits.

9. Monitor Usage and Feedback: Continuously monitor the usage patterns and gather feedback from patrons. This will help you identify any issues or areas for improvement in the subject classifications. Make necessary adjustments based on the feedback received.

10. Collaborate with Subject Experts: Collaborate with subject experts, librarians, or domain specialists to ensure the subject classifications align with current trends and developments in various fields. Their expertise can help refine and enhance the classification system.

By following these steps, you can effectively manage subject classifications for ease of patron browsing and searching, improving the overall user experience in your database or information retrieval system.

input: As a DB/IR administrator, I want to manage customizable relationship groups in support of patron see also option.
result:
As a DB/IR administrator, managing customizable relationship groups can greatly enhance the patron see also option. Here's how you can achieve this:

1. Define Relationship Groups: Start by defining various relationship groups that can be customized based on your specific requirements. For example, you might have relationship groups like "Related Books," "Similar Authors," or "Recommended Articles."

2. Determine Relationship Types: Within each relationship group, identify the different types of relationships that can exist. For instance, in the "Related Books" group, relationship types could include "Sequel," "Prequel," or "Same Genre."

3. Create Relationship Templates: Develop templates for each relationship type within a group. These templates will serve as a guide for users to input relevant information. For example, a template for the "Sequel" relationship type might include fields like "Title," "Author," and "Publication Year."

4. Enable Customization: Allow users to customize relationship groups by selecting the desired relationship types and arranging them in a preferred order. This flexibility ensures that patrons can see relevant information based on their interests.

5. Implement Data Entry Mechanism: Provide an intuitive data entry mechanism for users to input relationship details. This could be a form-based interface or a drag-and-drop functionality, depending on the complexity of the relationships.

6. Store Relationship Data: Design a database schema to store relationship data efficiently. Consider using a relational database management system (RDBMS) or a graph database, depending on the complexity and interconnectivity of the relationships.

7. Integrate with Patron See Also Option: Integrate the relationship groups and their corresponding data with the patron see also option. This could involve linking related items, authors, or articles based on the defined relationships.

8. Implement Search and Display Functionality: Develop search and display functionality that allows patrons to explore the relationship groups and view related items. This could include search filters, sorting options, and visual representations of the relationships.

9. Regularly Update and Maintain: Continuously update and maintain the relationship groups to ensure accuracy and relevance. This may involve periodic reviews, data cleansing, and user feedback analysis.

By managing customizable relationship groups, you can provide patrons with a comprehensive see also option that enhances their browsing experience and helps them discover related content more effectively.

input: As a Cornell faculty member, I want to search for the dissertations in the repository for which I have been a thesis committee member, to quickly find work by a former student.
result:
To search for dissertations in the Cornell repository for which you have been a thesis committee member, you can follow these steps:

1. Visit the Cornell University Library website (https://www.library.cornell.edu/) and navigate to the "Research" or "Search" section.

2. Look for a search bar or a specific section dedicated to searching the repository or dissertations. It may be labeled as "Digital Commons," "eCommons," or "Theses and Dissertations."

3. Enter relevant keywords related to your former student's work, such as their name, research topic, or keywords from the title. You can also try searching with your own name to find dissertations where you were listed as a committee member.

4. Refine your search results by selecting the appropriate filters, such as "Thesis/Dissertation" or "Author/Advisor/Committee Member."

5. Browse through the search results to find the dissertation(s) you are looking for. The search results should display the title, author, and other relevant information.

6. Click on the title or author's name to access the full dissertation. You may be prompted to log in with your Cornell credentials if necessary.

7. Once you have accessed the dissertation, you can read, download, or save it for further reference.

If you encounter any difficulties or cannot find the desired dissertations, consider reaching out to the Cornell University Library's support or reference desk for assistance.

input: As a library staff member, I want to make digital items held in trusted external system searchable within our system, so that I can provide seamless access to disparate collections.
result:
User Story: As a library staff member, I want to make digital items held in trusted external systems searchable within our system, so that I can provide seamless access to disparate collections.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. The library system should have the capability to integrate with external systems and retrieve metadata about digital items.
2. The integration should be able to authenticate and establish a secure connection with the external systems.
3. The library system should provide a search interface where users can search for digital items across both internal and external collections.
4. The search results should include relevant metadata about the digital items, such as title, author, description, and availability.
5. Clicking on a search result should provide users with a seamless way to access the digital item, either by directly opening it or by redirecting them to the external system's interface.
6. The integration should be able to handle updates and changes in the external systems, ensuring that the search results remain up-to-date.
7. The library staff should have the ability to configure and manage the integration with external systems, including adding new systems, modifying existing connections, and removing outdated connections.
8. The integration should be reliable and performant, ensuring that search queries across disparate collections are executed efficiently.
9. The library system should provide appropriate error handling and logging mechanisms to troubleshoot any issues with the integration.
10. The integration should comply with relevant privacy and security regulations, ensuring the protection of user data and maintaining the confidentiality of external system credentials.

input: As a researcher, I want to have information that will help me identify other faculty I might partner/collaborate with.
result:
To identify potential faculty members for collaboration, you can follow these steps:

1. Research within your own institution: Start by exploring the faculty members within your own institution who are working in your field of interest. Look for their research profiles, publications, and areas of expertise. Attend departmental meetings, seminars, and conferences to network and learn about ongoing projects.

2. Utilize academic databases: Use academic databases like Google Scholar, PubMed, Scopus, or Web of Science to search for researchers in your specific field. These platforms allow you to find publications, citations, and collaborations of faculty members worldwide. Look for researchers who have published in reputable journals and have a strong research track record.

3. Attend conferences and workshops: Participate in conferences, workshops, and symposiums related to your research area. These events provide excellent opportunities to meet and interact with other researchers, including potential collaborators. Engage in discussions, present your work, and network with attendees to identify like-minded researchers.

4. Join professional associations and societies: Become a member of professional associations and societies relevant to your research field. These organizations often have directories or member databases that can help you identify potential collaborators. Attend their meetings, conferences, and networking events to connect with researchers who share your research interests.

5. Collaborative research platforms: Explore online platforms specifically designed for researchers seeking collaborations, such as ResearchGate, Academia.edu, or LinkedIn. These platforms allow you to create a profile, showcase your research, and connect with other researchers worldwide. You can search for researchers based on their expertise, location, or research interests.

6. Seek recommendations: Reach out to your colleagues, mentors, or supervisors and ask for recommendations of faculty members they think would be suitable collaborators for your research. They may have insights into potential collaborators based on their own networks or previous collaborations.

7. Review funding agencies and grants: Look into funding agencies and grants that support research in your field. Often, these agencies provide lists of researchers who have received funding in the past. Review the profiles of these researchers to identify potential collaborators who have similar research interests.

Remember, when identifying potential collaborators, it is essential to review their research interests, expertise, and previous collaborations to ensure alignment with your own research goals. Reach out to them through email or professional networking platforms to express your interest in collaboration and discuss potential research projects.

input: As an externaluser, I want to easily find and access research and educational materials from Cornell faculty related to a particular topic, which I can use to develop stronger research/evidence based programming, grant proposals, community policy, or business practices.
result:
To easily find and access research and educational materials from Cornell faculty related to a particular topic, you can follow these steps:

1. Visit the Cornell University website and navigate to the "Faculty Research" or "Research and Publications" section.

2. Use the search function to enter keywords related to your particular topic of interest. For example, if you are interested in public health, you can search for "public health research" or "public health education."

3. Browse through the search results to find relevant research and educational materials from Cornell faculty. You may find academic papers, articles, reports, and other resources that can provide valuable insights and information.

4. Once you have identified the materials you are interested in, you can access them directly from the website or contact the faculty members or departments for more information.

5. Use the research and educational materials to develop stronger research/evidence-based programming, grant proposals, community policy, or business practices. You can cite the materials in your work and use the insights and findings to support your initiatives.

By following these steps, you can easily find and access research and educational materials from Cornell faculty to support your professional endeavors and contribute to the development of evidence-based practices.

input: As a student, I want to learn who at Cornell has or is engaged in research related to a particular topic, so that I can decide if I would like to pursue studies/research at Cornell.
result: To find out who at Cornell is engaged in research related to a particular topic, you can start by visiting the Cornell University website and exploring the faculty and research sections of the relevant departments. You can also reach out to the department directly and ask for information about faculty members who are conducting research in your area of interest. Additionally, you can search for academic papers and publications on the topic and see if any Cornell faculty members are listed as authors. Finally, you can consider reaching out to current students or alumni of Cornell to ask for recommendations or insights on faculty members who are conducting research in your area of interest.

input: As a student, I want to learn who at Cornell has or is engaged in research related to a particular topic, so that I can find an appropriate advisor, choose which courses to enroll in, and identify work/internship opportunities.
result:
To find researchers at Cornell University who are engaged in research related to a particular topic, you can follow these steps:

1. Visit the Cornell University website: Go to the official website of Cornell University (www.cornell.edu).

2. Navigate to the Research section: Look for a section or tab on the website that is dedicated to research. This section usually provides information about ongoing research projects, faculty members, and their areas of expertise.

3. Explore research departments: Within the research section, you will find various departments or schools dedicated to specific fields of study. Identify the department(s) that align with your topic of interest.

4. Browse faculty profiles: Within each department's webpage, there is usually a list of faculty members along with their profiles. These profiles often include information about their research interests, publications, and contact details.

5. Search for specific keywords: Use the search function on the Cornell University website to search for specific keywords related to your topic of interest. This will help you find relevant research centers, labs, or faculty members who are actively engaged in research in that area.

6. Read faculty publications: Once you have identified potential faculty members, search for their publications on platforms like Google Scholar or the Cornell University Library. This will give you a better understanding of their research focus and expertise.

7. Attend departmental events: Keep an eye out for seminars, conferences, or workshops organized by the departments related to your topic. Attending these events will allow you to meet faculty members, researchers, and fellow students who share your interests.

8. Contact potential advisors: Once you have identified researchers who align with your interests, reach out to them via email to express your interest in their research and inquire about potential advising opportunities. Be sure to introduce yourself, explain your background and interests, and ask if they are currently accepting new students.

9. Seek guidance from academic advisors: If you are unsure about which faculty members to approach or need further assistance, reach out to your academic advisor or departmental advisors. They can provide guidance and recommend specific faculty members who might be a good fit for your research interests.

Remember, it's essential to conduct thorough research and reach out to multiple potential advisors to increase your chances of finding the right fit for your academic and research goals.

input: As a teachingfacultymember, I want to identify timely and relevant research suitable for use in my curriculum, and be notified of new research/content.
result:
To identify timely and relevant research suitable for use in your curriculum and stay updated on new research/content, you can follow these steps:

1. Subscribe to academic journals and publications: Identify reputable journals in your field and subscribe to their email alerts or RSS feeds. This way, you will receive notifications about new research articles and content as they are published.

2. Join academic networks and communities: Join online platforms and communities specific to your field, such as ResearchGate or Academia.edu. These platforms often provide updates on the latest research and allow you to connect with other researchers and educators.

3. Set up Google Scholar alerts: Create alerts on Google Scholar for specific keywords or topics related to your curriculum. You will receive email notifications whenever new research articles matching your criteria are published.

4. Follow relevant researchers and institutions: Identify influential researchers and institutions in your field and follow them on social media platforms like Twitter or LinkedIn. Researchers often share their latest work and relevant content through these channels.

5. Attend conferences and workshops: Participate in conferences and workshops related to your field. These events provide opportunities to learn about cutting-edge research and network with other educators and researchers.

6. Collaborate with colleagues: Engage in discussions and collaborations with colleagues in your department or other institutions. They may come across relevant research or content that they can share with you.

7. Utilize online databases and search engines: Make use of online databases like PubMed, JSTOR, or IEEE Xplore to search for research articles and content relevant to your curriculum. These platforms often allow you to set up alerts for specific search queries.

By implementing these strategies, you can ensure that you stay informed about the latest research and find timely and relevant content to enhance your curriculum.

input: As a patron, I want to view multiple versions of a report/dataset to get both timely and historical information.
result:
User Story: Multiple Versions of Reports/Datasets

As a patron, I want to view multiple versions of a report or dataset so that I can access both timely and historical information.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. The system should provide a way for patrons to access different versions of a report or dataset.
2. Patrons should be able to easily switch between different versions of the same report or dataset.
3. The system should clearly indicate the version of the report or dataset being viewed.
4. Patrons should be able to view the changes made between different versions of the report or dataset.
5. The system should maintain a history of all versions of the report or dataset for reference.
6. Patrons should be able to filter or search for specific versions based on criteria such as date, author, or keywords.
7. The system should ensure that only authorized patrons can access different versions of the report or dataset.
8. Patrons should be able to download or export specific versions of the report or dataset if needed.

Additional Considerations:
- The system should provide a user-friendly interface for navigating and managing different versions of reports or datasets.
- It may be beneficial to implement a version control system or utilize versioning techniques to track changes and manage different versions effectively.
- The system should have appropriate security measures in place to protect the integrity and confidentiality of the different versions of reports or datasets.

input: As a faculty member, I want to upload my scholarly work to the repository, so that I can reach a non-academic audience, expand my influence within my academic community, and use it for teaching.
result:
To upload your scholarly work to the repository and achieve your goals, follow these steps:

1. Identify the appropriate repository: Research and select a reputable repository that aligns with your field of study and supports the type of scholarly work you wish to upload. Examples include institutional repositories, subject-specific repositories, or general repositories like arXiv or ResearchGate.

2. Review repository guidelines: Familiarize yourself with the repository's policies, guidelines, and terms of service. Ensure that your work meets their requirements and that you understand any copyright or licensing implications.

3. Prepare your work: Organize your scholarly work in a suitable format for uploading. This may include research papers, conference presentations, book chapters, or other relevant materials. Ensure that your work is properly formatted, proofread, and ready for public dissemination.

4. Check copyright permissions: Verify that you have the necessary rights to upload your work to the repository. If your work has been published elsewhere, review the publisher's policies regarding self-archiving or open access. If needed, seek permission or consider uploading preprints or postprints instead.

5. Create an account: Register for an account on the chosen repository. Provide the required information, such as your name, affiliation, and contact details. Some repositories may require verification of your academic credentials.

6. Upload your work: Follow the repository's instructions to upload your scholarly work. Provide relevant metadata, such as title, abstract, keywords, and publication details. Include any supplementary materials, such as datasets or multimedia files, if applicable.

7. Choose appropriate access settings: Decide on the access level for your work. You can make it openly accessible to the public, restrict access to registered users, or choose embargo periods if necessary. Consider your goals of reaching a non-academic audience and expanding your influence while respecting any contractual obligations.

8. Promote your work: Once your work is uploaded, share the repository link with colleagues, students, and other interested parties. Utilize your personal website, social media, or professional networks to increase visibility and encourage engagement with your work.

9. Monitor usage and impact: Regularly check the repository's usage statistics and citation metrics to gauge the impact of your work. This information can be valuable for tenure and promotion considerations, as well as for assessing the effectiveness of your teaching materials.

10. Utilize your work for teaching: Incorporate your uploaded scholarly work into your teaching materials. Share the repository link with your students, refer to it during lectures, or assign relevant readings. This will enhance the learning experience and expose students to current research in your field.

Remember to periodically update your repository profile and upload new scholarly work to maintain an active presence and continue expanding your influence within the academic community and beyond.

input: As a library staff member, I want to upload material to the repository on the author's behalf, so that I can fulfill a service obligation.
result:
User Story: As a library staff member, I want to upload material to the repository on the author's behalf, so that I can fulfill a service obligation.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. The library staff member should have the necessary permissions and access to upload material to the repository.
2. The staff member should be able to upload various types of materials such as books, articles, research papers, etc.
3. The staff member should be able to provide relevant metadata for the uploaded material, including author name, title, publication date, and any other required information.
4. The uploaded material should be stored securely in the repository and be easily accessible for library users.
5. The staff member should receive a confirmation or notification upon successful upload of the material.
6. The staff member should be able to track and manage the uploaded materials, including editing or removing them if necessary.
7. The system should provide a user-friendly interface for the staff member to easily navigate and upload materials.
8. The uploaded materials should be searchable and discoverable by library users through appropriate search functionalities.
9. The system should support file formats commonly used for library materials, such as PDF, EPUB, DOCX, etc.
10. The staff member should be able to upload multiple materials at once, if needed, to save time and effort.

Additional Considerations:
- The system should have appropriate storage capacity to accommodate a large number of uploaded materials.
- The staff member should be able to categorize the uploaded materials based on different criteria, such as subject, genre, or author.
- The system should provide options for the staff member to add additional information or descriptions to the uploaded materials, if desired.
- The staff member should be able to view statistics or analytics related to the uploaded materials, such as download counts or user feedback.
- The system should have backup and recovery mechanisms in place to prevent data loss in case of any technical issues or failures.

input: As a library staff member, I want to create metadata for items within the repository that includes document title, description, author, document type, status, file locations, subscribable flag, subject area, release frequency, and keywords for searching.
result:
To create metadata for items within the repository, you can follow these steps:

1. Document Title: Provide a clear and concise title for the item that accurately represents its content.

2. Description: Write a brief summary or abstract of the document to give users an idea of what it is about.

3. Author: Include the name of the author or creator of the document.

4. Document Type: Specify the type of document, such as book, article, report, thesis, etc.

5. Status: Indicate the current status of the document, such as draft, final, under review, etc.

6. File Locations: Include the file path or location of the document within the repository for easy access.

7. Subscribable Flag: Indicate whether the document is available for subscription or not.

8. Subject Area: Categorize the document under relevant subject areas or topics to facilitate browsing and searching.

9. Release Frequency: If applicable, specify the release frequency of the document, such as monthly, quarterly, annually, etc.

10. Keywords: Add relevant keywords or tags that describe the content of the document and will help users find it through searching.

By including this metadata for each item in the repository, you will enhance the discoverability and accessibility of the documents for library users.

input: As a library staff member, I want to upload large batches of items simultaneously, including descriptive metadata, so that I can offer service to authors efficiently.
result:
As an AI language model, I am not capable of uploading items or offering services to authors. However, I can suggest a possible solution for library staff members who want to upload large batches of items simultaneously with descriptive metadata.

One possible solution is to use a digital asset management system (DAM) that allows batch uploading of items with metadata. DAM systems are designed to manage digital assets such as images, videos, and documents, and they often come with features for organizing and searching assets based on metadata.

With a DAM system, library staff members can upload a large batch of items at once, and then add descriptive metadata to each item in bulk or individually. The metadata can include information such as title, author, date, subject, and keywords, which can help users find and access the items more easily.

Some popular DAM systems for libraries include DSpace, Islandora, and Omeka. These systems are open-source and free to use, and they offer a range of features for managing digital assets and metadata.

input: As a library staff member, I want to upload an item to the repository that will only become visible after a specific embargo period has expired, so that I can comply with author or publisher requirements.
result:
User stories are typically written from the perspective of the end user or customer, rather than the staff member. However, I can help you rephrase the user story to align with the user's perspective:

As a library user, I want to access an item in the repository only after a specific embargo period has expired, so that the library can comply with author or publisher requirements.

Alternatively, if you want to keep the user story from the staff member's perspective, you can use:

As a library staff member, I want to upload an item to the repository and set an embargo period, so that the item becomes visible to users only after the specified time has passed, in compliance with author or publisher requirements.

input: As an asset manager, I want to be assured that the digital copy I deposit is stored redundantly, so that when one copy suffers destruction or unwanted changes, I still have other good copies to restore from.
result: As an asset manager, ensuring redundancy for deposited digital copies is crucial. You can achieve this by utilizing cloud storage solutions that offer data redundancy features, such as RAID or erasure coding, to maintain multiple copies of your data across different locations. This way, if one copy is compromised, you can rely on the other copies for restoration.

input: As an asset manager, I want to be assured that threats to copies in one repository are not automatically incurred by the redundant copies.
result: As an asset manager, it’s important to ensure that redundant copies of digital assets are not simultaneously compromised by the same threats. This can be achieved by employing strategies such as isolating backup environments, using different security protocols for each copy, and regularly updating and patching systems to protect against known vulnerabilities.

input: As an asset manager, I want to be assured that the redundant copies are continuously monitored for unwanted changes, and that if/when changes do occur, there is a mechanism by which I can determine the original object and restore it to all copies.
result: As an asset manager, ensuring continuous monitoring of redundant copies for unwanted changes is crucial. You would want a system that not only tracks these changes but also allows you to identify the original object and restore it across all copies. Implementing IT asset management best practices, such as using asset management software for tracking and managing assets, can help in achieving this1. Additionally, data replication strategies can ensure that any changes in one copy do not affect the redundant copies, maintaining data integrity and availability2. Regular integrity checks can also be performed to identify discrepancies or unauthorized changes.

input: As an asset manager, I want to be assured that the assets can be taken out of the repository, and that the assets taken out are the same as those that are put in.
result: As an asset manager, to ensure that the assets withdrawn from the repository are identical to those deposited, you would want to implement a system that verifies the integrity of the assets during both deposit and withdrawal. This could involve checksums, digital signatures, or version control mechanisms to confirm that the assets remain unchanged.

input: As an asset manager, I want to know what the intellectual value of the asset is to the institution at the time of deposit, so that I obtain guidance in the evaluation of it for current value for the institution.
result: As an asset manager, to assess the intellectual value of an asset at the time of deposit, you would want to conduct an IP valuation. This process involves analyzing the potential future economic benefits, exclusivity, and enhancement of other assets associated with the IP. It’s crucial to understand the economic value of your IP assets for transactions, enforcement of IP rights, and internal management.

input: As an asset manager, I want to have a mechanism to obtain a listing or understanding of all the assets that have been deposited, and their current status.
result: As an asset manager, you would benefit from a system that provides a comprehensive listing and status overview of all deposited assets. input: As an asset manager, I want to be assured that funding and staffing of the IR have a commitment to longevity of the repository through published plans and/or explicit contract clauses.
result: As an asset manager, ensuring the longevity of the Institutional Repository (IR) through committed funding and staffing is crucial. input: As a stakeholder, I want to have files adequately described, so that I can successfully render them in my contemporary operating environment.
result: As a stakeholder, ensuring that files are adequately described is essential for successful rendering in your contemporary operating environment. input: As a library staff member, I want to preserve both the content and the metadata within the repository in a robust manner, so that I can provide stable, long-term access to this material.
result: To provide stable, long-term access to material in a repository, as a library staff member, you should employ metadata standards that support continuous preservation, discovery, and reuse of research data. Utilizing principles such as FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable), CARE (Collective Benefit, Authority to Control, Responsibility, Ethics), and TRUST (Transparency, Responsibility, User focus, Sustainability, Technology) will ensure robust preservation and accessibility of both content and metadata.

input: As a data curator, I want to upload a new version of an item that has changed, while still allowing old versions to be accessed.
result: As a data curator, you would want a system that supports version control, allowing you to upload updated versions of an item while preserving access to previous versions. This ensures that users can view and download both the latest and older versions of an item as needed.

input: As a library staff member, I want to preserve the scholarship of the law school by using sustainable links that will not succumb to link rot, so that I can create a permanent digital archive for the scholarship of my institution.
result: To preserve the scholarship of the law school effectively, you can use techniques such as robustifying links, which provides a proactive and uniform way to combat link rot. Additionally, employing best practices like linking to stable sites with high domain authority, regularly updating web content, and using proper redirects like 301 redirects can help maintain the integrity of your digital archive.

input: As a library staff member, I want to create a collection, sometimes with custom metadata fields, so that I can house digital material for wider distribution.
result: As a library staff member, to create a collection with custom metadata fields for housing digital material, you can utilize a content management system or library software that allows for the creation of custom metadata fields. This would involve defining the fields specific to your collection’s needs and ensuring they are indexed for searchability to facilitate wider distribution.

input: As a library staff member, I want to trace the list of revisors to determine who uploaded an item to the repository, so that I can confirm that proper procedures were followed.
result: As a library staff member, you would want a system that allows you to trace the revision history and identify who uploaded an item to the repository. This ensures that proper procedures are followed and maintains accountability. Utilizing version control systems or repository management tools that log user actions and changes can provide this functionality.

input: As an asset manager, I want to be assured that there is a formal plan for the disposition of assets if the IR should cease.
result: As an asset manager, you would want to ensure that there is a formal IT Asset Disposition (ITAD) policy in place for the Institutional Repository (IR). This policy should outline the procedures for decommissioning and disposing of assets, controlling data throughout its lifecycle, and complying with regulations. It’s essential to have a clear plan that addresses the disposition of assets to protect the business and meet compliance requirements.

input: As an asset manager, I want to have mechanism to pass ownership/management of the assets to a successor.
result: As an asset manager, you would want a structured succession plan that outlines the process for transferring ownership and management of assets to a successor. input: As a patron, I want to email system provider to report issues and ask questions.

input: As a data curator, I want to have a mechanism to allow for records scheduling for items that do not need to be stored indefinitely.
result: To schedule records for items that don’t need indefinite storage, implement a data management system with automated retention policies that define how long each record type is kept before deletion.

input: As a data curator, I want to upload a new version of an item that has changed, while still allowing old versions to be accessed.
result:
As a data curator, to manage item versions, you can:
Implement Version Control: Use a system that tracks changes and allows for version creation.
Enable Access to History: Ensure the system provides access to all historical versions.
Safeguard Data Integrity: Maintain the integrity of old versions when new ones are uploaded.
User-Friendly Interface: Offer a straightforward way for users to navigate between versions.
Compliance with Policies: Align the versioning process with your data governance policies.

input: As a user, I want to search and discover music using content identification or fingerprinting.

result: To obtain information about perceptually similar video items and segments, you can use techniques like superframe detection, which groups video frames with similar content patterns, or convolutional neural networks for feature extraction and perceptual hashing to compare and find similar video segments.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know when I should interrupt a volunteer.
result: The Zooniverse admin is looking for guidance on the appropriate times to intervene in a volunteer’s activity, ensuring a balance between project needs and volunteer experience.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know whether I should interrupt a volunteer with text, an image, or a video.
result: The Zooniverse admin is exploring the most effective way to interrupt a volunteer’s workflow, considering whether text, an image, or a video would be most appropriate for communication and engagement.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know when I should educate a volunteer.
result:
A Zooniverse admin should educate a volunteer primarily during these key moments:

Project Introduction: Clearly communicate the project’s goals and how volunteers’ contributions are vital.
Task Design: Ensure tasks are simple, clear, and avoid jargon. Use visual examples for guidance.
Pre-Launch: Conduct tests with non-experts and refine based on feedback to ensure the project is understandable and engaging.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know whether I should educate a volunteer with text, an image, or a video.
result:
To decide whether to educate a volunteer with text, an image, or a video, consider the following:

Text: Best for detailed instructions and easy updates. Allows for quick dissemination of information and is cost-effective.
Image: Effective for visual learners and can illustrate points that are hard to convey with text alone.
Video: Ideal for complex concepts, demonstrations, and creating engaging narratives.

input: As a Zooniverse admin,I want to know which piece of education I should give to a volunteer.
result:
To determine the most suitable educational content for a volunteer, consider these key points:

Assess the Volunteer’s Needs: Understand their learning objectives and areas of interest.
Content Relevance: Ensure the material is relevant to the volunteer’s role and the organization’s goals.
Engagement: Choose content that is engaging and interactive to maintain the volunteer’s interest.
Accessibility: Make sure the content is accessible, considering factors like language and technical requirements.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know when a volunteer has made an interesting comment on a subject.
result: To know when a volunteer has made an interesting comment on a subject in Zooniverse, look for comments that are insightful, add value to the discussion, and are relevant to the project’s goals. Engaging comments that prompt further discussion or provide unique perspectives are often considered interesting.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know when Zoonibot should comment on a subject.
result: Zoonibot should comment on a subject when it can provide helpful information, answer questions, or guide volunteers in their tasks, ensuring the interaction is relevant and adds value to the discussion.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know when Zoonibot should give an explanation.
result: Zoonibot should provide an explanation when a volunteer requests information, when there’s a need to clarify project-related tasks, or when engaging in discussions that benefit from additional context.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to know what Zoonibot should say to a volunteer.
result: Zoonibot should offer encouragement, express gratitude, provide guidance, and share information relevant to the volunteer’s tasks and interests in a positive and supportive manner.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to group subjects by similarity.
result: To group subjects by similarity in Zooniverse, you can create Subject Sets based on common characteristics like the date of creation, structure of the data output, or data source. This helps in organizing the data for analysis and enhancing the volunteer experience.

input: As a Zooniverse admin, I want to recommend different projects to volunteers based on their previous experiences.
result: To recommend projects to volunteers based on their previous experiences in Zooniverse, analyze their past participation patterns, interests, and feedback. Then, match them with projects that align with their skills and preferences for a personalized experience.

result: To enable CONNECT to leverage the Carequality framework for exchanging data with other Carequality participants, you should integrate CONNECT with the Carequality Interoperability Framework. This will allow seamless data sharing across different health information networks that are part of the Carequality ecosystem.

result: A CONNECT Adapter can handle requests both synchronously and asynchronously, allowing for immediate responses or processing them in the background without blocking other operations.

result: As a CONNECT administrator or security officer, you can view audit events through the System Administration module to effectively monitor audit logs and events.

input: As a CONNECT administrator, I want CONNECT to push audits and events via web services
result: As a CONNECT administrator, you would want the system to automatically send audit logs and events to other systems or applications using web services.

input: As a CONNECT administrator, I want the ability to logout of the admin GUI application
result: As a CONNECT administrator, having the ability to log out of the admin GUI application is crucial for maintaining the security and integrity of the system. This feature ensures that unauthorized access is prevented and sensitive information is protected. Logging out also helps in managing user sessions effectively, ensuring that each session is properly closed after use. It’s an essential part of user access management within any secure application.

input: As a CONNECT adopter (VA), I want CONNECT to be upgraded to the latest version of Hibernate so that my implementation is compliant with VA requirements and for security reasons
result: As a CONNECT adopter for the VA, upgrading to the latest version of Hibernate is essential for compliance with VA requirements and enhancing security. The most current version of Hibernate, as of the latest information, is 6.4.4, which includes minor improvements and bug fixes. Ensuring that CONNECT is updated to this version aligns with the VA’s commitment to using secure and reliable technology standards, as outlined in their policies. This upgrade is a proactive step in maintaining the integrity and security of the system, which is critical for protecting sensitive data within the VA ecosystem.

input: As a CONNECT adopter certifying for Meaningful Use Stage 2, I want CONNECT 4.x to pass validation using the NIST tool so that my implementation can be validated for MU
result: As a CONNECT adopter aiming for Meaningful Use Stage 2 certification, it’s crucial to ensure that CONNECT 4.x passes the NIST validation tool. This step is necessary to meet the compliance standards and secure validation for Meaningful Use, which is a key requirement for healthcare technology implementations under the HITECH Act. Successfully passing this validation signifies that the system adheres to the required health IT standards and can be deemed reliable and secure for use within the healthcare sector.

input: As a CONNECT adopter e.g. CMS-CCSQ and VA, I want CONNECT to be implemented using Java 1.6 on WL 11g so that I could use CONNECT in my preferred environment
result: As a CONNECT adopter, such as CMS-CCSQ and VA, implementing CONNECT with Java 1.6 on WebLogic Server 11g is desired for compatibility with preferred environments. This setup ensures that CONNECT aligns with specific organizational requirements and operates within the established IT infrastructure, providing a stable and compliant platform for health information exchange12. It’s important to note that while Java 1.6 is compatible with Oracle 11g, it is outdated and may not be supported with the latest security updates.

input: As a CONNECT adopter e.g. CMS-OFM and SSA, I want CONNECT to be implemented using Java 1.6 on WAS 7 so that I could use CONNECT in my WAS 7 environment
result: As a CONNECT adopter, such as CMS-OFM and SSA, implementing CONNECT using Java 1.6 on WebSphere Application Server (WAS) 7 would ensure compatibility with the existing WAS 7 environment. This approach aligns with the specific technological frameworks and standards of the organization, facilitating a seamless integration and operation within the established infrastructure1. However, it’s important to be aware that Java 1.6 is outdated and may not receive further updates, which could pose security risks.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I have a requirement to remove the reliance on the existence of the environment variable NHINC_PROPERTIES_DIR and to be able to find the CONNECT configuration files at run time using an instance-specific system variable.
result: As a CONNECT Adopter, the goal is to transition from depending on the NHINC_PROPERTIES_DIR environment variable to locating CONNECT configuration files at runtime using a system variable unique to the instance. This change would enhance the flexibility and portability of the CONNECT implementation, allowing it to adapt more easily to different environments and configurations. It’s a move towards a more dynamic and robust system setup that can cater to specific instance needs without manual environment variable setup.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I need a method of supporting higher volumes with multiple instances of the CONNECT gateway working together (User Story: U0002 & CLONE of GW438)
result: To support higher volumes, CONNECT Adopters can utilize multiple instances of the CONNECT gateway working in tandem. This approach allows for scalable and efficient handling of increased traffic and data loads. By leveraging strategies such as autoscaling and multi-attach capabilities, the system can dynamically adjust to the demand, ensuring consistent performance and reliability.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I need a type of redaction engine for document query and document retrieve. This would be a process of removing data from the response message.
result: As a CONNECT Adopter, implementing a redaction engine for document query and retrieval is crucial for protecting sensitive information. This engine would automatically remove specific data from response messages, ensuring that only authorized information is shared and maintaining compliance with privacy regulations. It’s an essential feature for any system handling confidential data, providing an additional layer of security.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I need a way to increase gateway performance for PD & QD requests by removing current limitation for serial request handling for same patient to multiple communities. (User Story: U0006 & GW442)
result: To enhance gateway performance for Patient Discovery (PD) and Query Document (QD) requests, CONNECT Adopters can implement parallel processing strategies. This would remove the bottleneck of serial request handling for the same patient across multiple communities, allowing for simultaneous data exchanges and faster overall response times. Utilizing modern application gateways with autoscaling and load balancing capabilities can significantly improve throughput and efficiency.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I need CONNECT to be database independent and support different databases such as Oracle.
result: As a CONNECT Adopter, achieving database independence is key, allowing for the use of various databases, including Oracle. This flexibility ensures that CONNECT can be integrated into diverse IT environments, catering to different organizational needs and preferences. It’s a strategic move to make CONNECT a versatile tool for health information exchange, adaptable to any database infrastructure.

input: As a computer I need CONNECT to be database independent and support different databases such as Oracle.
result: For a computer, having CONNECT be database independent and support various databases like Oracle is crucial for flexibility and interoperability. This allows for seamless integration with different database systems, ensuring that CONNECT can operate effectively across diverse technological environments. It’s a strategic approach to make CONNECT adaptable and capable of meeting a wide range of database requirements.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I need CONNECT to provide support for both Online Certificate Status Profile (OCSP) and Certificate Revocation List (CRL) with validation.
result: As a CONNECT Adopter, it’s important to have support for both OCSP and CRL with validation to ensure the security and integrity of digital certificates. OCSP provides real-time certificate status checks, while CRL offers a list of revoked certificates. Integrating both methods enhances the robustness of the system’s security protocols.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter I need the ability to have both secure and unsecure interfaces on the Adapter side to increase my flexibility with implementing Adapters and interfacing with down stream systems.
result: As a CONNECT Adopter, having both secure and unsecure interfaces on the Adapter side is crucial for flexibility in implementation and interfacing with downstream systems. This dual-interface approach allows for a tailored security level, accommodating various data sensitivity requirements and ensuring compatibility with different system protocols. It’s a strategic choice that enhances the adaptability and interoperability of the CONNECT platform.

input: As a CONNECT adopter I want installation instructions on how to configure and deploy CONNECT 4.x to be FIPS 140-2 compliant on a WebLogic 11g app server so that I can install CONNECT in my secure environment
result: To configure and deploy CONNECT 4.x for FIPS 140-2 compliance on a WebLogic 11g app server, you’ll need to enable FIPS mode in WebLogic Server and ensure the use of FIPS-compliant cryptographic modules. This involves setting up Java options for FIPS mode, updating the JDK’s security files, and creating FIPS-compliant keystores. These steps are critical for meeting the stringent security requirements necessary for a secure environment.

input: As a CONNECT adopter I want installation instructions on how to configure and deploy CONNECT 4.x to be FIPS 140-2 compliant on a WebSphere 7.0 app server so that I can install CONNECT in my secure environment
result: To install CONNECT 4.x on a WebSphere 7.0 app server for FIPS 140-2 compliance, you’ll need to configure the server to use FIPS-compliant cryptographic modules. This involves enabling FIPS mode in WebSphere, updating cryptographic libraries to FIPS-certified versions, and ensuring all cryptographic operations adhere to the FIPS 140-2 standards. These steps are essential to maintain the security and integrity required in a secure environment.

input: As a CONNECT adopter I want installation instructions on how to configure and deploy CONNECT to be FIPS 140-2 compliant on JBoss app server so that I can install CONNECT in my secure environment
result: To install CONNECT for FIPS 140-2 compliance on a JBoss app server, you’ll need to configure the server to use FIPS-compliant cryptographic modules. This includes setting up the server environment according to FIPS 140-2 standards and ensuring all cryptographic operations are performed using certified modules. Detailed instructions can be found in the official JBoss documentation.

result: The Release Notes for CONNECT 4.3 are documented on the wiki, detailing new features, bug fixes, and improvements. This includes enhancements to the Setup Wizard, updates to the core codebase, and security improvements. input: As a bug I want Release Notes for 4.3 to be documented on the wiki, so that I understand the features, bug fixes packaged with this release
result: If a bug were to access the Release Notes for version 4.3, it would find a comprehensive list of features and bug fixes that have been documented on the wiki. This documentation serves to inform users about the latest updates, ensuring they are aware of all the changes and improvements made in this release. input: As a CONNECT adopter I want Release Notes for 4.4 to be documented on the wiki, so that I understand the features, bug fixes packaged with this release
result: The user is requesting a concise summary of the Release Notes for CONNECT version 4.4 to be documented on the wiki. This documentation will help them understand the new features and bug fixes included in this release.

input: As a CONNECT adopter receiving Direct messages, I need the ability to provide Negative delivery notification message to the Sending STA so that the sender may be informed of a failed delivery.
result: The user is requesting the capability for CONNECT adopters who receive Direct messages to send a Negative Delivery Notification to the Sending Service Trading Agent (STA). This feature would notify the sender about the failure of message delivery.

input: As a CONNECT adopter receiving Direct messages, I need the ability to provide Positive delivery notification message(MDN) to the Sending STA so that the sender may be informed of a successful delivery.
result: The user is seeking a feature for CONNECT adopters to send a Positive Delivery Notification (MDN) to the sender’s Service Trading Agent (STA), confirming that a Direct message has been successfully delivered. This functionality ensures communication reliability and sender awareness of the message status.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages I want to have the ability to request delivery notification messages from Receiving STAs, so that I am informed of a successful or failed delivery.
result: The user desires a feature in CONNECT for senders of Direct messages to request delivery notifications from the recipients’ Service Trading Agents (STAs). This would enable the sender to be notified whether the delivery was successful or failed.

input: As a mail sending Direct messages I want to have the ability to request delivery notification messages from Receiving STAs, so that I am informed of a successful or failed delivery.
result: The user is requesting a feature for mail senders using Direct messages to be able to ask for delivery notifications from the recipients’ Service Trading Agents (STAs). This ensures the sender is informed about the message’s delivery status, whether it’s successful or not.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to have the ability to inform the Sending STA that I am using Processed notifications for delivery tracking
result: The user is seeking to implement a feature within CONNECT that allows senders of Direct messages to notify the Sending Service Trading Agent (STA) that they are utilizing ‘Processed’ notifications for tracking message delivery.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive a failure notification when the message I initiated was not sent to the Receiving STA so that I am informed of a failed delivery
result: The user is requesting a notification feature for CONNECT that alerts the sender of Direct messages when a message fails to be sent to the intended recipient’s Service Trading Agent (STA), ensuring the sender is aware of the delivery issue.

input: As a book sending Direct messages, I want to receive a failure notification when the message I initiated was not sent to the Receiving STA so that I am informed of a failed delivery
result: The user is looking for a feature that allows books, as entities sending Direct messages, to receive failure notifications if their messages are not successfully sent to the recipient’s Service Trading Agent (STA), ensuring senders are notified of unsuccessful deliveries.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive a failure notification when the Receiving STA's SMTP infrastructure rejects the message, so that I am informed of the failure and can take necessary next steps.
result: The user is asking for a feature in CONNECT that would allow senders of Direct messages to be notified if the recipient’s SMTP infrastructure rejects the message. This notification would inform the sender of the failure, enabling them to take appropriate actions.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive a notification when positive or negative delivery notification message is received by the gateway from the Responding STA, so that I am informed of a successful or failed delivery
result: The user is seeking a notification mechanism in CONNECT for senders of Direct messages. This feature would alert them when the gateway receives either a positive or negative delivery notification from the Responding Service Trading Agent (STA), indicating the success or failure of the message delivery.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive an error notification when the Initiating gateway cannot accept my message due to some reason, so that I can take necessary next steps.
result: The user is requesting a feature for CONNECT that would notify the sender of Direct messages when the Initiating Gateway is unable to accept their message. This error notification would allow the sender to be aware of the issue and take the necessary subsequent steps.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive failure notification when a Processed MDN message is not received from the receiving STA in a configured timeframe, so that I can monitor messages that could have failed.
result: The user is requesting a feature in CONNECT for senders of Direct messages to be alerted if a ‘Processed’ Message Disposition Notification (MDN) is not received from the recipient’s Service Trading Agent (STA) within a set timeframe. This would enable the sender to track and be informed about potential message failures, ensuring timely awareness and the ability to address any issues promptly.

input: As a CONNECT adopter sending Direct messages, I want to receive failure notifications when no requested delivery notifications are received from the receiving STA in a defined time, so that I can monitor messages that could have failed.
result: The user is seeking a feature in CONNECT that would provide failure notifications to senders of Direct messages if the requested delivery notifications are not received from the recipient’s Service Trading Agent (STA) within a specified timeframe. This function is crucial for monitoring and managing messages that may not have been successfully delivered, ensuring the sender is promptly informed of any potential issues.

input: As a CONNECT adopter supporting deferred PD services I would like to know about the requests that were fanned out by the gateway to multiple target communities so that I can keep track of the responses as I receive them.
result: The user is expressing a need for a tracking system within CONNECT for deferred Patient Discovery (PD) services. They want to be informed about the requests distributed by the gateway to various target communities, enabling them to monitor and manage the incoming responses effectively.

input: As a CONNECT adopter supporting Deferred PD services, I need the MessageID for the fan-out requests to be unique so that the service is spec compliant
result: The user is requesting that for CONNECT adopters who support Deferred Patient Discovery (PD) services, the MessageID assigned to each fan-out request must be unique. This requirement is essential to ensure that the service adheres to the specified compliance standards, allowing for accurate tracking and differentiation of each request.

input: As a CONNECT adopter testing the gateway against CCHIT's DIL, I want to have a reusable set of SOAP UI tests that validate PD, QD and RD initiating and responding scenarios, so that we can easily test and validate against the DIL.
result: The user is looking for a set of reusable SOAP UI tests for CONNECT that validate Patient Discovery (PD), Query Document (QD), and Retrieve Document (RD) scenarios, both initiating and responding. These tests are intended to facilitate easy and efficient validation against the Certification Commission for Health Information Technology’s (CCHIT) Direct Implementation Lab (DIL).

input: As a CONNECT adopter using Direct I do not want to relay MDN notifications back to the edge to avoid redundant notifications and inorder to be spec compliant
result: The user is looking for a way to streamline the notification process within CONNECT when using Direct. They want to avoid sending Message Disposition Notification (MDN) back to the edge, which can create unnecessary redundancy. Ensuring this process is in line with specifications is also a priority for compliance purposes.

input: As a CONNECT adopter using Direct transport, I want CONNECT to be kept up to date with the Direct Reference Implementation and Direct Implementation guides so that the community can make use of success/failure delivery notifications and trust bundles
result: The user is advocating for the CONNECT platform to stay current with the Direct Reference Implementation and Direct Implementation guides. This update is crucial for the community to effectively utilize delivery notifications, both success and failure, as well as trust bundles, which are essential for secure and reliable message exchanges in healthcare communications.

input: As a CONNECT adopter using Direct, I want all delivery notifications sent or received from the remote STA or the edge to be logged in the CONNECT event logs so that I can troubleshoot and track message delivery
result: The user is requesting a feature for CONNECT that logs all delivery notifications, whether sent or received, from the remote Service Trading Agent (STA) or the edge. This logging is crucial for troubleshooting and tracking the delivery of Direct messages, ensuring a reliable audit trail and facilitating issue resolution.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter utilizing CONNECT I need to understand at the individual message field level the meaning of each field and how CONNECT is using it for Patient Discovery.
result: The user is seeking a detailed explanation of each message field within CONNECT, specifically for Patient Discovery. They require clarity on the purpose and usage of each field to understand how CONNECT processes and utilizes the data for patient identification and data exchange in healthcare systems. For comprehensive insights, the user can refer to resources that explain HL7 message structures and the Cross-Community Patient Discovery specifications

input: As a CONNECT adopter, I need CONNECT to log auditing transactions to the audit repository asynchronously in order to improve performance
result: The user is requesting that CONNECT, as a healthcare interoperability platform, should log auditing transactions to the audit repository asynchronously. This approach is aimed at enhancing performance by reducing the immediate load on the system, allowing for more efficient processing of healthcare data exchanges and interactions12. Asynchronous logging can help in managing large volumes of audit data without impacting the core functionalities of the CONNECT platform

input: As a CONNECT adopter, I want to instruct the gateway which spec version/endpoint to target for QD service so that I have greater flexibility when exchanging with my trading partners.
result:
To target a specific spec version/endpoint for the QD service in the CONNECT gateway, you can:

Log into the Admin GUI: Access the administrative interface of the gateway.
Specify the Spec Version: Choose the appropriate spec version for the QD service.
Set the Endpoint URL: Enter the corresponding endpoint URL for the selected spec version.
Save the Configuration: Apply and save the changes to enable communication with the desired trading partners.
Test the Setup: Verify the configuration by testing connectivity with the QD service.
This setup ensures seamless integration and exchange with various trading partners using different versions of the QD service.

Access the Admin Interface: Log into the gateway’s administrative panel.
Select the RD Service: Locate the RD service settings within the interface.
Input Spec Version: Choose the required spec version for the RD service.
Enter Endpoint URL: Provide the corresponding endpoint URL for the chosen spec version.
Save and Test: Save the settings and conduct a test to ensure proper connectivity.
This process allows for flexible interactions with different trading partners’ systems.

input: As a CONNECT adopter, I want to know how to enable FIPS on a CONNECT 3.3 installation on GlassFish 3.1.2
result:
To enable FIPS on a CONNECT 3.3 installation on GlassFish 3.1.2, you would typically:

Update the Domain Configuration: Edit the domain.xml file to include the FIPS-related settings.
Install the FIPS-compliant Provider: Add a FIPS-compliant security provider such as OpenSSL or NSS to the GlassFish server.
Configure the Provider: Set up the security provider to operate in FIPS mode through the GlassFish admin console or asadmin utility.
Restart GlassFish: Apply the changes by restarting the GlassFish server.
Please note that specific steps may vary based on the security provider and the system configuration.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter, I want to know that upgrading CONNECT won't break my current ability to exchange information and my working adapters in order to lower the hurdles to upgrading (User Story: U0005 & CLONE of GW441)
result:

Review the Release Notes: Check for any changes that might affect your current setup.

Follow Best Practices: Adhere to recommended upgrade procedures provided by the CONNECT documentation.
By taking these steps, you can minimize the risk of disrupting your current information exchange capabilities and adapter functionality during an upgrade.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter, I want to process and send large payload sizes of up to 1 GB to meet the requirements of all my use cases (User Story: EST010 & CLONE of GW473)
result:
To process and send large payloads up to 1 GB in CONNECT, consider the following steps:

Optimize Data Serialization: Use efficient serialization formats like JSON and enable compression to reduce payload size.
Leverage Streaming: If possible, stream data in chunks instead of sending it all at once to manage memory usage effectively.
Increase Timeout Settings: Adjust the timeout settings to accommodate the longer processing time required for large payloads.
Utilize Robust Infrastructure: Ensure that both the sending and receiving systems have the necessary resources to handle large payloads.

input: As a CONNECT Adopter, I want to process and send large payload sizes of up to 1 GB to meet the requirements of all my use cases (User Story: EST010)
result:

Optimize Serialization: Use efficient serialization methods like JSON and enable compression.
Stream Data: Implement streaming to process and send data in chunks.
Adjust Timeouts: Increase timeout settings to accommodate the processing of large payloads.
Ensure Infrastructure Capacity: Verify that the infrastructure can support large data transfers.
These steps will help you meet the requirements for processing and sending large payloads.

input: As a CONNECT adopter, I would like CONNECT SAML handling to conform completely to the NwHIN specifications
result:
For CONNECT SAML handling to fully conform to NwHIN specifications, you should:

Adhere to NHIN Authorization Framework: Ensure SAML assertions meet the standards outlined in the NHIN Authorization Framework Specification.
Implement SAML 2.0: Use SAML 2.0 for conveying requestor’s authentication, identification, and consent policies as per NwHIN guidelines.
Follow Digital Signature Requirements: Include proper digital signatures in SAML assertions to align with NwHIN Exchange Architecture.

input: As a CONNECT developer, I want to implement static code analyzers in CONNECT via maven and jenkins, to understand the quality of code.
result:
o implement static code analyzers in CONNECT via Maven and Jenkins, follow these steps:

Choose appropriate static code analyzer tools such as SonarQube, Checkstyle, PMD, or FindBugs.
Integrate the selected static code analyzer tool into your Maven project configuration. This typically involves adding the necessary plugin configurations to your project's pom.xml file.
Set up Jenkins to automate the static code analysis process. Create a Jenkins job specifically for running static code analysis.
Configure the Jenkins job to trigger code analysis whenever a new code commit is made to the repository.
Configure Jenkins to generate reports based on the static code analysis results. This could include generating HTML reports, sending notifications, or integrating with external dashboards.

input: As a CONNECT developer, I want to include the security plugin for findbugs, to help identify security vulnerabilities in CONNECT.
result:
To include the security plugin for FindBugs in CONNECT:

Add Dependency: Update your project's Maven configuration (pom.xml) to include the FindBugs Security Plugin dependency.

Configure FindBugs Plugin: Configure the FindBugs plugin in your Maven project to enable security checks. Specify the appropriate configuration options in your project's pom.xml file to enable security checks.

Integrate FindBugs into Jenkins Pipeline: If you're using Jenkins for continuous integration, integrate FindBugs into your Jenkins pipeline. Add a stage in your Jenkinsfile to run FindBugs security checks as part of the build process.

Review FindBugs Security Reports: After running the FindBugs security checks, review the generated reports to identify any security vulnerabilities in your CONNECT project.

Address Security Vulnerabilities: Take appropriate actions to address the security vulnerabilities identified in the FindBugs security reports. This may involve code changes, configuration updates, or other security measures to mitigate the identified risks.

Continuous Monitoring: Make running FindBugs security checks a regular part of your development process to continuously monitor the security of your CONNECT project. Regularly review and address any new security findings to ensure the ongoing security of your application.

By following these steps, you can include the security plugin for FindBugs in CONNECT and help identify and address security vulnerabilities in your project.

input: As a CONNECT tester, I would like to have a thorough set of regression tests for Patient Discovery, so that I can have proper test coverage
result:
To perform regression testing for Direct functionality in CONNECT, follow these steps:

Test Planning:

Review the Direct features and functionalities in CONNECT to identify areas that require regression testing.
Create a test plan outlining the scope, objectives, and test scenarios for regression testing Direct functionality.
Test Case Design:

Design test cases covering various aspects of Direct functionality, including message sending, receiving, routing, encryption, decryption, and error handling.
Ensure test cases cover both positive and negative scenarios to validate different use cases.
Test Environment Setup:

Set up a test environment that mirrors the production environment as closely as possible.
Configure the environment to support Direct messaging, including necessary certificates, directories, and configurations.
Regression Testing Execution:

Execute the designed test cases to verify the functionality of Direct features.
Validate that existing features work as expected and have not been affected by recent changes or updates.
Verify interoperability with other systems and compliance with Direct standards.
Data Management:

Prepare test data, including sample Direct messages, attachments, and metadata, to use during regression testing.
Ensure test data covers a wide range of scenarios to thoroughly validate Direct functionality.
Defect Management:

Document any defects or issues identified during regression testing.
Prioritize and track the resolution of defects to ensure they are addressed in a timely manner.
Automated Testing:

Explore opportunities for automation in regression testing Direct functionality.
Implement automated test scripts for repetitive or complex test scenarios to improve efficiency and accuracy.
Reporting and Documentation:

Generate test reports detailing the results of regression testing for Direct functionality.
Document any changes made, defects identified, and lessons learned during regression testing.
Continuous Improvement:

Iterate on the regression testing process based on feedback and findings from each testing cycle.
Incorporate improvements to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of regression testing for Direct functionality.
